(15 points, suggested time 25 minutes) A block slides back and forth on a track with a slight circular curvature, where friction is negligible, as shown above. The maximum height <math alttext="uppercase H" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>H</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> of the track at each end is much smaller than <math alttext="uppercase D" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>D</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. The center of mass of the block oscillates between <math alttext="x equals negative uppercase D" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>−</mo><mi>D</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="x equals positive uppercase D" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>+</mo><mi>D</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. The curve is so gradual that the total distance traveled along the curved portion of the track by the center of mass of the block can be considered to be <math alttext="2 times uppercase D" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2</mn><mi>D</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. At time <math alttext="lowercase t equals 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> the block is released from rest at position <math alttext="x equals positive uppercase D" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>+</mo><mi>D</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. The period of the block’s oscillation is 2.0 seconds. (a) Which of the graphs above, Graph 1 or Graph 2, could represent the block’s kinetic energy as a function of its position on the circular track, and which graph could represent the horizontal component of the net force acting on the block as a function of its position on the track? The curve is so gradual that the total distance traveled along the curved portion of the track by the center of mass of the block can be considered to be <math alttext="2 times uppercase D" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2</mn><mi>D</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. At time <math alttext="lowercase t equals 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> the block is released from rest at position <math alttext="x equals positive uppercase D" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>+</mo><mi>D</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. The period of the block’s oscillation is 2.0 seconds. (a) Which of the graphs above, Graph 1 or Graph 2, could represent the block’s kinetic energy as a function of its position on the circular track, and which graph could represent the horizontal component of the net force acting on the block as a function of its position on the track? Justify both of your choices with physics principles.
(b) Choose one of the graphs in part (a) above and explain how the graph shows evidence that a restoring force is acting on the block.

(c) Graph 3 above incorrectly shows the horizontal velocity of the block as a function of time. Identify a feature of the graph that does not correctly represent the motion of the block. Justify your answer.

(d) Track 2, shown above, has a horizontal length that is greater than that of Track 1 and the same maximum height <math alttext="uppercase H" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>H</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. The block is released from rest at position <math alttext="x equals positive 2 times uppercase D" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>D</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> Is the period of the block’s oscillation on Track 2 greater than, less than, or equal to the period of oscillation on Track 1? Justify your answer.

(e) A student derives the following equation for the period T of the block’s oscillation: <math alttext="uppercase T equals, 2 pi times the square root of the fraction with numerator lowercase h squared, and denominator 2 times lowercase d times g, end fraction " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>T</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>π</mi><msqrt><mrow><mfrac><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>h</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mi>d</mi><mi>g</mi></mrow></mfrac></mrow></msqrt></mrow></mstyle></math>, where <math alttext="lowercase d" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>d</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is the maximum displacement of the block from equilibrium and <math alttext="lowercase h" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>h</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is the height of the track at <math alttext="x equals lowercase d" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>d</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. Whether or not this equation is correct, is the equation consistent with your answer to part (d)?

(f) On Track 1, shown above again for reference, friction is negligible and the center of mass of the block oscillates between a horizontal position of <math alttext="positive uppercase D" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>+</mo><mi>D</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="negative uppercase D" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>−</mo><mi>D</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> with a period of 2.0 seconds. If a sphere with a mass equal to that of the block were to roll without slipping between <math alttext="positive uppercase D" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>+</mo><mi>D</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="negative uppercase D" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>−</mo><mi>D</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> along Track 3 shown above, which is identical to Track 1 but has nonnegligible friction, would the period of the motion of the sphere be greater than, less than, or equal to 2.0 seconds? Justify your answer.
